Award.AwardTitle: Biochemical Excellence in Science and Technology (BEST)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Milwaukee Area Technical College (MATC) is addressing local and national initiatives to increase the number of students transitioning to baccalaureate degrees in STEM disciplines through the Biochemical Excellence in Science and Technology (BEST) program. The primary goals of this project are to strengthen the Associate of Science degree program and offer students different tracks within this degree, most notably in the biochemical sciences. Enrollment in all STEM fields is expected to increase. This five-year project offers an array of recruitment, academic support and enrichment activities to ensure academic success and stimulate interest as students explore career pathways in science and technology when education and research are integrated. It includes summer workshops for high school seniors, research internships for college students in cooperation with four-year institutions and businesses, and a STEM-focused professional development course for high school teachers and counselors. The program is open to all, but minorities, women and other under-represented populations are major target groups for recruitment. The BEST program provides a model for integrating student learning and research through development of curriculum and key partnerships with research institutions. The bridge internships create stronger transfer relationships between MATC and local colleges and universities. More importantly, there is a broader impact on the number of technicians to meet the workforce development needs of Wisconsin business and industry, where biochemical science and technology provides some of the fastest growing job opportunities in the state.

Institution.Name: Milwaukee Area Technical College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: MILWAUKEE AREA TECHNICAL COLLEGE FOUNDATION, INC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to increase the number of students, particularly women and members of groups underrepresented in the sciences, in the Milwaukee Area Technical College’s associate of science and other STEM programs. This increase in students would lead to more graduates with associate’s degrees who could then be either employed or transfer to a baccalaureate degree program. The one curricular area significantly strengthened through this project were the biochemical sciences.

Over the lifetime of the grant a modest increase (3 more students per year) in chemical technologies students occurred. A more significant increase (12 more students per year) occurred in the number of biological sciences students. While more students enrolled in the sciences, this unfortunately did not lead to a significant increase in either graduates or transfers to 4 year institutions. The loss of one PI in 2013 (moved to another state), the loss of a second PI (deceased in 2015) and the retirement of a co-PI (left the institution in 2015) presented challenges which impacted the project, but other MATC faculty maintained the program for the remaining duration of the grant.

Over the lifetime of the grant, 350 students enrolled in the biology and chemistry areas available at MATC when BEST recruitment activities were being offered. Nine local partners (industry and public health partners) provided internships and mentoring to BEST students over the life of the grant. Over the 4 years (2011-12, 2012-13, 2013-14, and 2014-15) 12 interns were offered either full or part-time positions at their intern sites, after the internship. With the loss of grant leadership in 2015, these intern data were no longer reported, but the working relationships between MATC and these partners remain a valuable outcome of this grant. Biology curriculum developed by this project has been institutionalized at MATC.


Last Modified: 09/28/2018
Modified by: Jeanne M Hossenlopp
